s1: Cyber Security Foundations introduces all essential cyber security principles.
s2: Demonstrate a working understanding in the ethical concerns of data drive analysis and experiments in human behavior.

s1: This includes principles of secure design, secrets minimization, least privilege, isolation, separation and encapsulation.
s2: This includes random graph models, homophily and friendship paradox, influence and contagion in networks, markets and network games, network resilence.

s1: The interplay between failed security principles and vulnerabilities is investigated in detail.
s2: Demonstrate a working understanding in the ethical concerns of data drive analysis and experiments in human behavior.

s1: The course provides the essential foundations which allow students to continue in a more in-depth cyber security career, yet can also be used a standalone unit to provide a self-contained set of knowledge.
s2: The course equips the students with in-depth knowledge and hands-on experience in working with network data to study social processes at both the individual and aggregate levels.

s1: Demonstrate a thorough understanding of the fundamental principles underlying Cyber Security.
s2: Demonstrate a thorough understanding of the fundamental principles of using computational approaches to formulate and answer social science questions.

s1: Define and identify cyber security principles and their violation.
s2: Analyze results from network algorithms, and articulate their limitations.

s1: Apply cyber security principles in a practical context.
s2: Apply network analysis algorithms in practical contexts.

s1: Migrate insights from cyber security analysis into new designs.
s2: Demonstrate a working understanding in the ethical concerns of data drive analysis and experiments in human behavior.

s1: Communicate a cyber security thread to a heterogenous team of professionals.
s2: Communicate the process of formulating and solving computational social science problems to a team of professionals with computing and/or social sciences.
